message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles: Control Methods and Future Challenges
Paper Abstract: With the rapid development of computer technology, automatic control technology and communication technology, research on unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has attracted extensive attention from all over the world during the last decades. Particularly due to the demand of various civil applications, the conceptual design of UAV and autonomous flight control technology have been promoted and developed mutually. This paper is devoted to providing a brief review of the UAV control issues, including motion equations, various classical and advanced control approaches. The basic ideas, applicable conditions, advantages and disadvantages of these control approaches are illustrated and discussed. Some challenging topics and future research directions are raised.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've performed a web search for "motion equation physics". Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Fundamentals

In physics, equations of motion are equations that describe the behavior of a physical system in terms of its motion as a function of time.(no content)A differential equation of motion, usually identified as some physical law (for example, F = ma), and applying definitions of physical quantities, is used to set up an equation to solve a kinematics problem.

## Mathematical Formulation

An equation of motion is a function of the position of the object, its velocity (the first time derivative of position), and its acceleration (the second derivative of position), and time.

## Newton's Laws and Motion Equations

Web search results for query: "Unmanned aerial vehicle"

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

Here's what I found about unmanned aerial vehicles:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs), and a UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903, as a way of testing airships without risking human life.

## Modern Development

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone at a price of $629, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications.(no content)Civil uses include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, and delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "flight control system"

Links: [{"title":"Aircraft flight control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_flight_control_system"},{"title":"Intelligent flight control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_flight_control_system"},{"title":"Flight control modes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_control_modes"},{"title":"Flight control computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_control_computer"},{"title":"Flight controls - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_controls"},{"title":"Fly-by-wire - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fly-by-wire"},{"title":"Control loading system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loading_system"},{"title":"Helicopter flight controls - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helicopter_flight_controls"},{"title":"Fight-or-flight response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fight-or-flight_response"},{"title":"Uninterruptible autopilot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uninterruptible_autopilot"}]

## Flight Control System - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about flight control systems. Here's an overview based on the search results:

### Basic Definition
A conventional fixed-wing aircraft flight control system consists of flight control surfaces, the respective cockpit controls, connecting linkages, and the necessary operating mechanisms to control an aircraft's direction in flight.

### Types of Control Systems

**Mechanical Systems:**
A manual flight control system uses a collection of mechanical parts such as pushrods, tension cables, pulleys, counterweights, and sometimes chains to transmit the forces applied to the cockpit controls directly to the control surfaces.(no content)The Cessna Skyhawk is a typical example of an aircraft that uses this type of system.

**Hydraulic Systems:**
Hydraulically powered control surfaces help to overcome the limitations of mechanical systems, allowing the aircraft's size and performance to be limited by economics rather than a pilot's muscular strength.

**Fly-by-Wire Systems:**
Fly-by-wire (FBW) is a system that replaces the conventional manual flight controls of an aircraft with an electronic interface.(no content)A pilot commands the flight control computer by moving the control column or sidestick, and the flight control computer then calculates what control surface movements will cause the plane to perform that action and issues those commands to the electronic controllers for each surface.

### Flight Control Computers
A flight control computer receives and processes data from a multitude of sensors throughout the aircraft that monitor variables such as airspeed, altitude, and attitude (the aircraft's orientation in three-dimensional space).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Fly-by-wire (FBW) is a system that replaces the conventional manual flight controls of an aircraft with an electronic interface.(no content)A pilot commands the flight control computer by moving the control column or sidestick, and the flight control computer then calculates what control surface movements will cause the plane to perform that action and issues those commands to the electronic controllers for each surface.

### Flight Control Computers
A flight control computer receives and processes data from a multitude of sensors throughout the aircraft that monitor variables such as airspeed, altitude, and attitude (the aircraft's orientation in three-dimensional space).

I've completed a web search for "automatic control." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A control system manages, commands, directs, or regulates the behavior of other devices or systems using control loops.(no content)Control engineering, also known as control systems engineering and, in some European countries, automation engineering, is an engineering discipline that deals with control systems, applying control theory to design equipment and systems with desired behaviors in control environments.

## How Automatic Control Works

In the simplest type of an automatic control loop, a controller compares a measured value of a process with a desired set value and processes the resulting error signal to change some input to the process, in such a way that the process stays at its set point despite disturbances.

## Types of Control

Fundamentally, there are two types of control loop: open-loop control (feedforward), and closed-loop control (feedback).(no content)In open-loop control, the control action from the controller is independent of the "process output" (or "controlled process variable"). A good example of this is a central heating boiler controlled only by a timer, so that heat is applied for a constant time, regardless of the temperature of the building.

## Applications

It can range from a single home heating controller using a thermostat controlling a domestic boiler to large industrial control systems which are used for controlling processes or machines.

## Historical Development

The first feedback control device on record is thought to be the ancient Ktesibios's water clock in Alexandria, Egypt, around the third century BCE. It kept time by regulating the water level in a vessel and, therefore, the water flow from that vessel.

Web search results for query: "autonomous flight"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Boeing Passenger Air Vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Passenger_Air_Vehicle"},{"title":"Urban air mobility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_air_mobility"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Multi-spacecraft Autonomous Positioning System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-spacecraft_Autonomous_Positioning_System"},{"title":"Starship flight test 7 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starship_flight_test_7"},{"title":"Starship flight test 2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starship_flight_test_2"},{"title":"Bluefin-21 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bluefin-21"},{"title":"Festo SmartBird - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Festo_SmartBird"},{"title":"Veronte Autopilot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veronte_Autopilot"}]

I've performed the web search for "autonomous flight" and retrieved comprehensive results. Here's a summary of what I found:

## Key Findings on Autonomous Flight

**What is Autonomous Flight?**

Autonomous control employs multiple control-loop layers, decomposing the aircraft's behavior into manageable "chunks", or states, with known transitions.(no content)The flight of UAVs may operate under remote control by a human operator, as remotely piloted aircraft, or with various degrees of autonomy, such as autopilot assistance, up to fully autonomous aircraft that have no provision for human intervention.

**Current State of Development**

Some modern drones have a high degree of autonomy, although they are not fully capable and the regulatory environment prohibits their widespread use in civil aviation.(no content)A number of air taxis are under development and larger autonomous transports are also being planned.

**Technology and Systems**

UAV software called the flight stack or autopilot obtains data from sensors, controls motors to ensure UAV stability, and facilitates ground control and mission planning communication.(no content)Artificial intelligence and machine learning are necessary to develop autonomous craft, but pose a complication to certification because they are non-deterministic, i.e. they may behave differently given the same input in the same scenario.

**Recent Developments**

In 2024, the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) approved the certification basis for Veronte Autopilot under the ETSO-C198 framework, making it the first flight control system for UAS and eVTOL to undergo this process.

The search results cover autonomous aircraft systems, unmanned aerial vehicles, air taxi development, and various autopilot technologies currently in use or development.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"); relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes); entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other; wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/); relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
